Hal McGee.title: Unlocking The Secret Codes
Hal McGee.about:
a collaboration 

Visual artist Nonlocal Variable’s electronic sounds from the early 1980s mixed together with Hal McGee’s dictaphone recordings from June 2025. We offer these recordings with love and joy to you, our listeners. You complete the audio art by attentive listening!



Nonlocal Variable is a visual artist from the Pacific Northwest, part of the Cascadia Mail Art Alliance. Between 1975-77, he hosted live Avant Garde “new” music, often using tape loops running across a room between two reel-to-reel tape recorders. In the early ‘80s, he fooled around with instruments for personal pleasure. Playing stopped, and NLV focused on corresponding artists in the DIY cassette culture – which led him to join the Fluxus/Mail Art community. Decades later, the only recorded music left was a cassette of random electronic noodling on a 1981 Casiotone VL-TONE-VL-1 portable synthesizer, recorded on a Revox B-77 reel-to-reel recorder. He was inspired by Hal McGee’s latest electronic psychogeographic collaborations and thought it would be cool to see what they could put together.



From June 24th through 30th 2025 Hal McGee collected more than 120 recordings on two Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones in Gainesville, Florida: the sounds of his daily life including his dog Stanley, neighbors and family members, and spoken words; as well as electronic sounds made with his Casio VL-Tone that he bought in 1983, Casio CT-S200 RD, circuit bent Casio SK-1, Stylophone CPM DS-2 analog synthesizer, and KQ Unotone and John Cage Prepared Piano iPhone apps

— with the participation of Kestrel Sky, who played the Borderlands Granular iPad app in an impromptu jam with Hal on KQ Unotone in Ben’s car after lunch at Metro Diner.



On June 30th Hal mixed together Nonlocal Variable’s Casiotone recordings along with his own dictaphone recordings played back in random shuffle mode and created an audio assemblage blending together sounds from many different times and locations.

Hal McGee.title: Narvon-Gainesville Sound Capsule
Hal McGee.about:
a collaboration

dictaphone assemblage audio art

a multi-layered collage of

500+ short recordings of everyday sounds & electronics

recorded March 2025



STRATTANPOSSUM

For this project I used my Yemenren 16 bit digital recorder, or as I like to call it, my Wrigglie's gum recorder, making 225 recordings ranging from a little over a minute to only a few seconds in length.

I recorded sounds from my wide arsenal of circuit bent toys, keyboards and devices like my beloved Tapeworm circuit bent cassette player, and unbent tablehooters such as the Yamaha YPT 230 and the Casio CTK 571, in combinations with or without my Korg SQ1 sequencer, Zoom 70CDR effects pedal, Ucreate music mixer, Arcade Pocket Operator, and Monotron Delay.



Additionally you will hear the sounds of such things as water, wind chimes, answering machine messages, telemarketers, recitations of Edgar Allan Poe, March winds, pause/record collages from old cartoons and random cable TV channels, fragments of Charles Ives and Miles Davis, breaking glass, short wave radio, the massaging of wet balloons, Monotron Duo, electric kazoo, maniacal laughing, walking in dry leaves, rattling contents of the recycle bin and the electro acoustic Strattanpossum "Pep Boys Special Pet Nightmare Noise Machine” among many other intriguing sounds.



All of the recordings were made in the month of March 2025 on the grounds of Possum Ranch in Narvon, Pennsylvania and at various locations in North Eastern Lancaster County, Pennsylvania.



HAL MCGEE

from March 1-31, 2025 I collected 266 recordings of sounds of my daily life in Gainesville, Florida

using two Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphones

— co-starring Stanley

with electronic sounds by and voice of Dylan Houser

the voices of my brother, my mom and her dog Bailey

Andrew Chadwick, Joshua Rogers,Trevor & Ben Luke

Stylophone CPM DS-2 synthesizer

circuit bent Casio SK-1

sounds from Squared Wave shows

and Action Research # 244

Krishna Lunch

bird songs of the Stanozoic or Halozoic

emergency vehicle sirens

ukulele glee club singers and street musicians

Clockwork Orange or some shit

vacuum cleaner, fire alarm, power saw, leaf blowers



On March 31, 2025

I created a chance-derived assemblage

by playing Strattanpossum’s recordings

on two KLIM Nomad CD players

in random playback mode

and my recordings on the two Sony dictaphones

in shuffle playback mode

and recorded the mix directly into Audacity

as it happened, with no post-production

Hal McGee.title: Rastro Sonido
Hal McGee.about:
Dear Friends! Welcome to our Rastro Sonido! Welcome to our Flea Market of Sound! We recorded the sounds on Rastro Sonido from March 24th through May 18th, 2024 with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones in Tenerife (Canary Islands, Spain) and Gainesville, Florida (USA). Dictaphone assemblage audio folk art.



We loaded our 472 recordings onto four PX-470s, and on May 24th we mixed the sounds together using a random chance process by playing them back in random/shuffle mode, and we recorded the mix directly into Audacity with no post production.



You will hear sounds from many different times, places, and spaces simultaneously juxtaposed in a multi-layered audio collage. Rastro Sonido is an immersive, friendly, joyful, celebratory audio art experience. Step inside with an open mind and imagination. You complete the art!



Rafael's sound sources: trumpet, voice, turntable, field recordings, an appointment at a dental clinic, Casio PT-1, Alesis Microverb 4, laptop, Korg Volca Modular, metallophone, shortwave, acoustic guitar and objects.



Hal's sound sources: Yamaha Reface YC mini-organ, Yamaha Reface CS mini-synth, dumpster floor tom, circuit bent Casio SK-1, two string pink dumpster guitar, transparent plastic ukulele, recordings of the sounds of my daily life, with the participation of my dog Stanley.



On YouTube you can watch a six-minute RASTRO SONIDO movie consisting of photos and short video clips, along with many of the same sounds that you will hear on the audio album — 

youtu.be/ORMo3LhPh2A

Hal McGee.title: The Norden vs Gainesville Lost & Found Sound Duel
Hal McGee.about:
All sounds from Ostfriesland recorded by Brandstifter between 20th of March & 2nd of April for Asphaltbibliotheque Norden with the Olympus Digital Voice Recorder WS-311M during lost & found safaris in public space, in a mall and various supermarkets while shopping, during walks, at an Easter bonfire at Kolk Hof Luetetsburg, in Karin's car or in the house and garden of his girlfriend's mother in the city of Norden, as well as in the communities of Groothusen and Pilsum. Besides his voice he used the Casio SK-1 keyboard and various handheld Korg Monotron synths to perform his lost & found messages in interactions with animals & human beings, nature & the so-called civilization. 

www.brand-stiftung.net



 Hal McGee recorded the sounds of his daily life in Gainesville, Florida with the Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphone from the 1st through 11th of November 2024: Featuring Hal’s sound safari companion Stanley including Hal’s brother Mark, his mom and dad and their dog Bailey, neighbors and apartment maintenance workers, grocery store employees and people on the street, and neighborhood dogs and birds. Hal played the circuit bent Casio SK-1, KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, Yamaha Reface YC mini-organ, Sound Bites sound effects machine, two-string pink dumpster guitar, and transparent plastic ukulele.

On November 11th Hal created an assemblage of the sounds that Brandstifter and he had recorded. 

halmcgee.bandcamp.com

Hal McGee.title: Collaboramigos
Hal McGee.about:
Collaboramigos sounds like four friends sitting together in a virtual audio-chatroom, sharing thoughts and poems, conversing, playing random recordings of the sounds of their daily lives, telling jokes and stories, singing pop songs, and jamming on instruments in a playful, improvisational, free-flowing sound collage.



During the month of April 2025 Girls On Fire, Dylan Houser, Rafael González, and Hal McGee gathered recordings of various sounds. In early May they mixed their sounds together using a chance process.



The album is perhaps best experienced as a continuous one-hour piece, but we understand that in life there are many distractions & things to do - jobs, family responsibilities, the cat needs to be fed, the dog needs to be walked, meals need to be prepared, etc. - so we have indexed the recordings in four parts of roughly equal length. We encourage you to listen to this album while you are doing other things, if you want.



*Girls On Fire (Leslie Singer) sound sources & devices

Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphone

Staples Easy Button

Keychain guitar

Cheap & Plastic pink keyboard

Black & White Monotron

Desktop fire extinguisher

Clips from:

- Narvon-Gainesville Time Capsule by Strattonpossum and Hal McGee

- Lectures by Laura Cottingham

- Featuring various sounds from the NYC subway and mean streets



*Dylan Houser recorded their dang recordings with a SONY ICD-PX470 starting on the very first day of the month of April (a holiday of utter damnation). Sound sources used: voice, birds chirping, bugs buzzing, alligators gromping, wading water, electric guitar, HiChord synth, rumble of ancient times, chained-up contact mic built by Michael Ridge, Roland Microcube, NADY mixer, KQ Unotone, NOINPUT Mixer app, Relic Wave, acoustic bass guitar, beach waves, conversations, bawk bawk bawking, other people talking, various assorted field recordings and other noise devices I may have forgotten to list here…now go and eat your dang ol’ chicken tikka masonna.



*Rafael González sound sources & devices:

my voice, field recordings, objects, appliances, furniture, metallophone, trumpet, manipulated tapes, radio FM & shortwave, Google translator app for smartphone, Casio SK1 Sampling Keyboard, sound box and toy megaphone.



*Hal McGee sound sources and devices:

my dog Stanley, my brother Mark, my mom, my sister & her family, various thoughts & words, neighborhood sounds, train whistle and bell, Behringer Poly D synthesizer, miscellaneous recordings from Apartment Music shows #52 and #53.

Hal McGee.title: Stipulations Without Frontiers
Hal McGee.about:
Dylan Houser and Hal McGee recorded the sounds of Stipulations Without Frontiers from January 1-23, 2025 with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones in Lakeland and Gainesville, Florida. On January 27th we created a dictaphone assemblage by playing our 274 recordings on four PX-470s in random/shuffle mode, and we recorded the mix directly into Audacity with no post production.



Dylan Houser: voice (demonic or otherwise), percussion, HiChord pocket synthesizer, door harp, wind chimes, oversized Christmas bell, blowing bubbles in a beverage with a straw, celebrity impersonations, automobiles passing by, foot steps, sprinklers, the air, fm radio, shortwave radio, not needing AI, button pressing, NOINPUTMIXER app, Koala app, TikTok samples, running water, unidentified clanging, pocket shuffling, and various assorted outdoor field recordings (and some indoor, too)



Hal McGee: sounds of my daily life, spoken words, my dog Stanley, neighbors and family, sending postal mail, conversations with Charles Rice Goff III and a former co-worker and Trevor Luke, crows and whippoorwills, Yamaha ReFace CS synth, airplanes and helicopters, Steinway baby grand piano, Yamaha Reface YC mini-organ, two string pink dumpster guitar, medical staff and hospital sounds, flowing water, circuit bent Casio SK-1, leaf blowers and garbage trucks, transparent plastic ukulele, Casio VA-10, Casio VL-Tone.



This album is dedicated to the immortal memories of Harold McGee (June 13, 1936-January 9, 2025) and Chef Jakether Black-Houser (ca. 2014-January 28, 2025).

Hal McGee.title: May The Fourth Be With You!
Hal McGee.about:
This was one of the first potential specials that sprang to mind when Don Campau offered me a show on the KOWS Radio Summit towards the end of last year. The names of Hal McGee and Electronic Cottage were already iconic in the Cassette Culture Hall Of Fame (well there SHOULD be!) when I first got involved with the network at the onset of the nineties, so it's great to be able to make some small contribution towards the legend. It was an enormous pleasure (if a bit of a long haul!) putting the show and this album together, I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I have. The original broadcast has now been archived online for your eternal pleasure, I'll put the link at the end.

Thanks for listening,

Mick Magic (May 2024)



Links;

KOWS 92.5 FM -  kows92-5.org

 Dr. Magic's Audio Lab -  www.mickmagic.net

 Electronic Cottage -  www.electroniccottage.org

 The Show -  archive.org/details/kowsradiosummit/Radio+Summit+_Dr+Magic's+Audio+Lab_+5-4-24.mp3

Hal McGee.title: The Bubblegum Variations
Hal McGee.about:
The Bubblegum Variations consists of more than 350 recordings by Arvo Zylo and Hal McGee mixed together in a chance process assemblage.



Arvo Zylo’s notes for The Bubblegum Variations:

— Hal McGee has been recording experimental music and noise since 1981. Arvo Zylo was born in 1981, and has been active since the year 2000. For this project, Arvo initially intended to contribute solely walkie talkie recordings of himself from 2014 and 2015; “Image streaming” in a free association, dream-like style. This audio has largely not been listened to by Arvo since shortly after it was recorded.

— That single creative spark gave way to other ideas, which included harmonium & toy pipe organ (thanks to Jason Lazer), and also stems from rare, long out of print tapes, unreleased recordings sometimes dating back to 2001, various field recordings, and occasional attempts at singing.

— Some of the recordings included a Yamaha RM1x Sequencer, a Casio SK-1 knock off called an “SS330”, some elements of the Korg Elektribe series, two Line6 Delay Pedals, a haunted BOSS Micro BR handheld recorder, a USB handheld recorder, a coronet, a belt sander, a sampler, a smart phone, and a laptop.

— Thanks Hal for your friendship!



Hal McGee’s notes for The Bubblegum Variations:

— I was quite happy in mid-May 2025 when Arvo proposed that we do a collaboration. I immediately started making recordings with two Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones, of sounds from my daily life, diaristic entries, my dog Stanley, my brother Mark McGee, circuit bent Casio SK-1, Stylophone CPM DS-2 analog synthesizer, KQ Unotone iPhone synth, Haltoid noise box, sounds from the Apartment Music 54 and May Squared Wave shows.

— and with contributions by my friends Ben Keselowsky, Josh Tippery, Alex Smith, and Lenny Pearlman.

— Most of all, thanks to Arvo Zylo for this opportunity to collaborate!



Home-brewed CD-Rs of The Bubblegum Variations are available for sale and trade from Hal McGee —  haltapes@gmail.com

Hal McGee.title: Automated Interchange Pileup
Hal McGee.about:
a chance-constructed assemblage of hundreds of everyday, found, electronic, junk, improvisational, and noise sounds



on February 7, 2025 W.A.Davison wrote to Hal:

 Hey, Hal! I read your article on the Electronic Cottage website and was reminded that you are on my list of recipients for this new album.

 W.A.Davison "500" is a collection of 500 samples and loops that can be listened to as an audio "cut-up" (play it in shuffle mode and it's a new album each time) or can be used in sound collages/compositions of your own. It marks the occasion of my 500th release as a musician/sound artist.



Hal replied to William:

 W.A.Davison "500" arrived perfectly configured to work well with my usual dictaphone assemblage method!

 I want to create a dictaphone assemblage album consisting of most of your 500 recordings mixed together with an equivalent amount of recordings by me.

— I have four Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones, which record and playback 16-bit WAV files.

— During the month of February I will make recordings of various & 'random' sounds onto two of the four dictaphones.

— At the end of the month I will load your recordings onto two of the four dictaphones.

— To create the assemblage I will connect all four dictaphones to a mini-mixer, recording directly into Audacity.

— I will then simultaneously playback the recordings on all four dictaphones in Shuffle Mode, thus creating a four-layered sound collage, with no post-production or re-mixing... just 'as it happens'.

— The four-layered sound collage will then be arbitrarily broken into tracks of roughly the same length.



—————————————————————



The recordings included on W.A.Davison "500" span more than four decades, so any kind of comprehensive equipment list is out of the question. Instead, here is an off-the-top-of-my-head list of recording equipment, instruments, etc. that I have used at various times:



- various homemade instruments (Three-String Electric Crutch, Nog Nister, The Nice Device, etc.)

- Atari 1040 STe running Cubase midi sequencer

- several Apple computers running Logic

- numerous PCs running linux OS with free and open source software (Audacity, Ardour, LMMS, Carla, Bespoke, etc.)

- Tascam Porta One four-track cassette recorder and Yamaha MT120 four-track cassette recorder

- Fostex R8 8-track open reel tape recorder and several Sony open reel tape recorders

- Soundcraft Spirit Folio 12/2 mixer

- various drum kits, drums, and percussion instruments

- various drum machines (Realistic Concertmate Electronic Accompaniment, Boss DR-55, Boss DR-110, Roland TR-505, Boss DR-550, etc.)

- various electric and acoustic guitars and electric bass guitars

- various hardware synthesizers (Yamaha CS-20M, Yamaha DX100, Korg Monotron series, etc.)

- various software synthesizers (TAL Noisemaker, ZynAddSubFX, Cardinal, Dexed, etc.)

- numerous cheap electronic keyboards (Casio, Realistic, Fisher-Price, etc.)

- found objects

- toys (musical or sound-producing)

- various guitar effects pedals (Boss RC-20 Loopstation, Boss DM-2 delay, Boss RV-5 reverb, Ibanez Metal Charger, etc.)

- various multi-effects processors (Zoom RFX-300, Korg Kaoss Pad, Roland SE-50, etc.)

- Amdek PCK-100 Percussion Synthesizer (kit built)

- Roland CP-40 pitch to midi converter

- various (mostly cheap) microphones

- various field recorders (Sony MZ-NF810 minidisc recorder, Zoom H1n, microcassette recorders, etc.)

- Warblers (modified cassette recorders)

- Nintendo DSi handheld game system

- numerous cassette recorders and modified turntables and record players



—————————————————————



Hal McGee’s sound sources and instruments

 recorded February 1st through 26th, 2025

 with two Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones



sounds of my daily life

spoken words

my dog Stanley

neighbors and grocery store employees

family (including my mom and her dog Bailey)

sending postal mail

circuit bent Casio SK-1

Casiotone CT-S200RD

Casio VL-Tone

Casio VA-10

Yamaha Reface YC mini-organ

Yamaha ReFace CS synth

Stylophone GEN X-1

Korg Volca Keys

KQ Unotone iPhone synth

two string pink dumpster guitar

transparent plastic ukulele

Squier Paranormal Cyclone electric guitar

Danish butter cookies tin

sounds of Action Research #243 (02-02-2025)

and Squared Wave (02-12-25) shows



—————————————————————



Notes from W.A.Davison “500":

 Five hundred samples and loops, randomly selected from the archives of The Recordists.

 A Disembraining Songs release, cat.# DIS-027, Jan. 23, 2025.

"500" is not only a collection of five hundred samples and loops, it is also my 500th release as a musician/sound artist. Discounting any possibly forgotten early tracks, or releases that have flown under the radar, I have been keeping track of every appearance of W.A.Davison (or Songs of the New Erotics, Six Heads, The Bim Prongs, etc.) that has been officially released to the public over the past 40 years. The discography includes appearances of my work as a musician/improviser/composer/sound artist on vinyl records, compact discs, cassettes and, more recently, digital releases on various netlabels, Bandcamp, etc. It also includes any other form of publishing/broadcasting where my work is publicly accessible, such as film and video soundtracks and radio, television, and internet broadcasts and appearances, so long as the streams/downloads remain available online.

 The samples and loops in this collection were selected randomly from the Recordist archives (cassettes, CD-Rs, videotapes, minidiscs, DATs, etc.) between July 5th, 2024 and Jan. 23, 2025.

 You will notice quite wide variations in the quality of audio collected here. I make no apologies for that as it's in the nature of a decades-spanning audio archive. High-fidelity was not a criteria for selection and, in fact, there were no criteria for selection. The collection truly is random. The only rule I set for the project was that no sample would be more than a minute long. In some cases I did make some minimal adjustments to the samples to make them more listenable, but for the most part the collection is presented "warts and all."

 The collection can be approached as a work of audio art. The tracks can be played in order as a kind of cut-up. Putting your audio player in shuffle mode creates a new work each time! (I would suggest removing the gap between tracks, if possible). Most tracks can also be played as loops, if you're into that sort of thing. The entire collection of 500 sound files makes for approximately 2.5 hours total listening time. Enjoy!



—————————————————————

Hal McGee.title: Officially Unofficial
Hal McGee.about:
Rafael González and Hal McGee invite you to spend an hour with us in our flea market (rastro) of sound! Rafael and Hal recorded the sounds on OFFICIALLY UNOFFICIAL from February 11th through March 17th, 2024 with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones in The Canary Islands (Spain) and Gainesville and St. Petersburg, Florida (USA).



We loaded our 534 recordings onto four PX-470s, and on March 24th we mixed the sounds together using a random chance process by playing them back in random/shuffle mode, and we recorded the mix directly into Audacity with no post production.



Rafael's sound sources: trumpet, my voice, bike helmet, folding sofa bed, doors, my voice, Casio PT-1, Alesis Microverb 4, laptop, paper and cardboard, plastic elements (bags, containers and bottles), mop, water, windows, cassettes, masher, reel-to-reel tape recorder, acoustic guitar, hand dryer, field recordings, Philips PMC 100 synthesizer, radio transistor and fluorescent lamp (Pedro Bericat style), Shortwave, Korg Monotron Delay (short circuits), air horn, whistle, walkie talkie, metal and wooden pieces.



Hal's sound sources: my voice, sounds of my daily life in Gainesville, Squier Paranormal Cyclone electric guitar, two string pink dumpster guitar, Casio CT-S200RD, circuit bent Casio SK-1, talking with my neighbors, my dog Stanley, KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, my brother Mark, and recordings from a trip that Mark and I took in February to St. Petersburg, Florida (to hang out with our friends Marguerite Sissie, Hal Harmon, and Dan Fox).



The OFFICIALLY UNOFFICIAL album cover is a photo collage consisting of 144 photos by Rafael and Hal taken during the time period of recording the audio.



You can watch a 5 and a half minute OFFICIALLY UNOFFICIAL movie consisting of photos and short video clips along with sounds from the audio album on YouTube - 

youtu.be/7gW_OPALso4

Hal McGee.title: COLLABORATORY
Hal McGee.about:
COLLABORATORY

Collage — Collaboration — Laboratory

dictaphone assemblage audio folk art

From September 1st through 30th 2023 Rafael González and Hal McGee made 445 dictaphone recordings in La Laguna, Canary Islands, Spain, and Gainesville, Florida, USA. At the end of September we mixed the recordings together using an automated random chance shuffle procedure. COLLABORATORY is one continuous immersive audio assemblage, which we have divided into six parts for the listener’s convenience (the sixth part is available as a bonus track in the download).



The listener completes the audio assemblage through active listening. Your mind will find patterns in the chaos. Have fun trying to figure it out!



Rafael recorded these sounds with a Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphone:

his voice, Korg Monotron, guitar, trumpet, MiniFreak V software, microcassettes, reel-to-reel tape recorder, shortwave, mixer, various objects such as pieces of paper, plastic bags and field recordings, and sounds of his daily life.



Hal recorded these sounds with two Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphones:

sounds of his daily life, co-workers, family, neighbors, his voice, circuit bent Casio SK-1, transparent plastic ukulele, two-string pink dumpster guitar, Casio CT-S200RD keyboard. Plus Hal recorded the sounds of Trevor and him playing Behringer Poly D and Behringer Odyssey analog synthesizers (with Source Audio Collider Delay & Reverb and Alesis Microverb III effects units).

You will also hear Hal's dog Stanley, of course!



Our friend Trevor Luke participated in COLLABORATORY. You will hear his voice engaging in conversation with Hal, and him playing analog synthesizers.



COLLABORATORY has been conceived, designed, developed, recorded, photographed, and assembled by Rafael González and Hal McGee, and it is a celebration of our friendship, and coffee, and brutal naps.

Hal McGee.title: Chance Encounters in the City
Hal McGee.about:
Chance Encounters in the City is a compilation of short sound works inspired by the idea of an imagined “chance encounter” with an artist or a source of artistic inspiration in a real or fictional city. The concept for this compilation was inspired by Lumen K’s real-life chance encounter with artists Hal McGee and Girls on Fire in the Bowery district of New York City, as pictured on the cover.

Compilation produced by Lumen K.

Contributors should direct message Trevor to receive free download codes.

Hal McGee.title: Trash Milagro
Hal McGee.about:
Trash Milagro was recorded November 1-30, 2023

with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones

in The Canary Islands, Spain and Gainesville, Florida, USA

~ dictaphone assemblage audio folk art ~

We offer Trash Milagro to you with joy, friendship, and love!



Rafael's sound sources:

my voice, Korg Monotron, Korg Monotribe, Smartphone (alarm, audio player, app's...), field recordings, objects and utensils (stones, pieces of metal, wood, plastic, tube, cups, teaspoon, microwave, washing machine, hand dryer ....), trumpet, body sounds, Alesis Microverb 4, Alto Professional ZMX 862 Mixer, manipulated cassettes, Korg Monotron Duo, Korg Volca Sample, Arturia MiniFreak V software, FM-AM and shortwave radio, short circuits on Korg Monotron Delay.



Hal's sounds sources:

my voice, my dog Stanley, my mom, my dad, my brother, Bailey (my mom and dad’s dog), co-workers, sounds from my job, circuit bent Casio SK-1, KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, two string pink dumpster guitar, transparent plastic ukulele, Hare Krishna musicians, musicians in hospital lobby, ice cream truck, traffic sounds, birds, airplanes and helicopters, U.S. Postal Service delivery lady, Hal speaks a bit of Esperanto (badly).



Hal's recordings feature our dear mutual friend Trevor Luke.

You will hear Trevor's voice, and Trevor and Hal playing Moog Grandmother and Behringer Poly D analog synthesizers.



Trash Milagro consists of 624 recordings that Rafael and Hal made during the month of December with small pocket-sized battery-operated digital dictaphones. At the end of the month we played these recordings on four dictaphones in random/shuffle mode and mixed them together with Audacity, with no additional effects. We exported 24-bit WAV files from Audacity and uploaded them directly to Bandcamp.



You will hear sounds from many different times, spaces, and places. Have fun listening to our trash!



Trash Milagro is an immersive 90-minute audio trash assemblage that is meant to be experienced as one continuous experience or happening. We have divided the assemblage into six 15-minute tracks for the listener's convenience.



We recommend downloading WAV files for optimum sound quality.

Hal McGee.title: request a free download code
Hal McGee.about:
The title of this album of dictaphone assemblage audio folk art by Rafael González and Hal McGee is "request a free download code". To request a free download code contact Rafael González on Facebook, and Hal McGee on Facebook and Instagram, and via the Bandcamp Contact Form. We offer this album of sounds to you with love, joy, and affection. We believe that the listener completes the music by listening attentively, but we also invite you to spend these 97 minutes just hanging out with us, and feel free to do other things as you listen if you want to...



Rafael and Hal recorded the sounds on "request a free download code" from January 1st through 31st, 2024 with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones in The Canary Islands (Spain) and Gainesville, Florida (USA). We loaded our 398 recordings onto four PX-470s, and on February 3rd we mixed the sounds together using a random chance process by playing them back in random/shuffle mode, and we recorded the mix directly into Audacity with no post production. 



sound sources of Rafael González:

Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphone, my voice, field recordings, plastic elements (bags, containers and bottles), cups, cutlery, microwave, toilet cistern, cardboard and paper , trumpet, body sounds, air horn, windows, doors, drawers, toothbrush, aluminum foil, Korg Volca Modular, FM radio, metal and wooden pieces, birds, metallophone, turntable, Korg Volca Sample, tinker bell, Arturia MiniFreak V software, toaster, water, Koto app, Philips PMC100 Composer, shortwave radio, Tar played by Neda Mehrjoo, the manipulated voice of Jerry Kranitz, Alesis MicroVerb 4 and laptop.



sound sources of Hal McGee:

recordings made with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphone, my voice, my dog Stanley, sounds recorded at Apartment Music shows 48 and 49 including the voices of the attendees, the voice of my special guest Little Fyodor including the sounds of him testing the gear he played at the Apartment Music shows, circuit bent Casio SK-1, Casio Casiotone CT-S200RD (played with fingers AND feet), KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, transparent plastic ukulele, sounds of family members (brother, Mom, Dad, sister and her family, including my mom and dad's dog, Bailey), and neighbors, me testing gear for AM 48 and 49, hospital sounds, a busking musician in downtown Gainesville, emergency vehicles and traffic sounds.



In the download we have included a special video that contains unique recordings including Birthday greetings to Hal from Nicolas Malevitsis, Seiei Jack, Wolfgang Müller, Niniji Chen, Markus Breuss, Mors Mea, Harold Schellinx, Khaing Su, Mindaugas Žuromskas, Leslie Singer, Antonella Eye Porcelluzzi, Michel Madrange (M.Nomized) and Neda Mehrjoo.

Hal McGee.title: Rocket in My Pocket compilation
Hal McGee.about:
Rocket in My Pocket, an Electronic Cottage Compilation

Curated and produced by Leslie Singer

Inspired by Hal McGee’s “Cheap and Plastic” compilation series, “Rocket in My Pocket” is a collection of 26 tracks from artists all over the globe using only instruments and sound makers of any kind that fit into one’s pocket. This included toys, small wind instruments, bird whistles, mini digital audio recorders and synths of all kinds as well as smartphones. It just needed to be a sound device that fits into a jacket or pants pocket. Effects pedals were allowed. Much thanks to all the wonderful artists who contributed to Rocket in My Pocket. A special thank you to Hal McGee for the encouragement, inspiration, and the publishing of this compilation. Enjoy! — Leslie Singer

Hal McGee.title: Columbus Trip
Hal McGee.about:
Columbus Trip

was recorded July 20th through 23rd, 2023

with four Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphones

in Columbus, Ohio and Gainesville, Florida

dictaphone assemblage audio folk art

featuring Chris Phinney, Jeff Chenault, and Jerry Kranitz

with the voices of Lisa Miralia and other attendees

of the Cassette Culture Celebration on the 22nd.

...and of course Stanley

On July 28th I mixed the recordings together using a random shuffle procedure, creating an audio assemblage in which you will hear audio events from many different times, spaces, and places. The continuous 72-minute audio assemblage is divided into four roughly equal parts for the listener’s convenience.



The listener completes the audio assemblage through active listening. If you have never heard this kind of audio art before and you find it bewildering, perhaps just think of it as four talk radio shows playing simultaneously on your car radio, or the aural sensations you might experience at a county fair or a circus, or maybe four films being simultaneously projected. Your mind will find patterns in the chaos. Have fun trying to figure it out!



On Thursday, July 20th 2023 I took an airplane flight from where I live in Gainesville, Florida to attend the Cassette Culture Celebration on Saturday, July 22nd, in Columbus, Ohio, which was curated and produced by Jeff Chenault, and by Alison Colman of The Fuse Factory.



I met Chris Phinney at the Atlanta airport and we sat next to each other on the plane flight to Columbus. Jeff Chenault met us at the Columbus airport and took us back to his house, which would be our home for the next three days.



On Thursday at 5:00 PM the three of us traveled to John and Cathy Bennett's house, where we met Jerry Kranitz. This was a joyous time for all of us! Until that day Chris had never met Jeff, Jerry, John and Cathy. The six of us went to dinner at the nearby Iron Grill restaurant at 5295 North High Street. More hanging out and conversing with Cathy and John inside their art- and book-filled home followed.



On Friday Jerry picked Chris and me up at 6:00 AM and we traveled to the Stauf's coffeehouse at 1277 Grandview Avenue (where I had a triple macchiato to get sufficiently caffeinated for the exciting day ahead). After Stauf's Jerry, Chris and I went to Grand Day Cafe (1284 West 5th Avenue) for breakfast. Mid morning Jeff showed Chris and me the gear setup for our improvisational performances on Saturday, and we hung out in his amazing three basement rooms of records, tapes, art, cassette culture memorabilia, synthesizers, and exotica treasures. At 11:00 AM we met Jerry at El Vaquero Mexican restaurant at 3230 Olentangy River Road. After lunch we traveled to Columbus Performing Arts Center at 549 Franklin Avenue, to check out the space and gain technical setup info for the event on Saturday. Friday afternoon was fun-filled with a stop at the amazing Used Kids Records store at 2500 Summit Street, then a stop for coffee at Cup O Joe (2990 North High Street), and then back to Jeff's for more hangout time and listening to records. Late afternoon Jeff, Chris, and I ate dinner at Panini Opa Greek restaurant at 4799 Sawmill Road. At 7:00 PM they dropped me off at John and Cathy Bennett's house, and the three of us conversed for three hours about William S. Burroughs, fluxus, poetry, and our art life experiences.



On Saturday morning Jerry picked me up from the Bennetts' house and we drove to Jeff's house to pick up Chris for early morning coffee at Starbucks. At 9:30 AM we met at Jeff's house and we all traveled to Cultural Arts Center to pick up sound system gear for the big event. At about 11:00 we loaded in all of the gear and display materials. You will hear bits and pieces of conversations and miscellaneous sounds from CPAC during the Cassette Cultural Celebration. We met many great and enthusiastic and joyful people there that day, too many people to list here, including old friends and new (including Brian Callahan who traveled from Indianapolis to attend). Included are sounds from the numerous sound art performances, and the cassette culture panel discussion moderated by Jerry in which Jeff, Chris and I shared our experiences and insights about our experiences in the 1980s, and what cassette culture means today. My entire solo performance with a handheld Monotron Duo analog synthesizer can be heard in the mix. 



Other great moments on Saturday include our mid-show break excursion to Schmidt’s Sausage Haus German restaurant at 240 East Kossuth Street to pick up dinner. Back at CPAC several of us sat around a big long table and ate and conversed: Rob from Saginaw, Otho Thorn and Knox Mitchell from Michigan, Michael Thomas Jackson from North Carolina, Endwar, Lisa, Jeff, Chris, Jerry, and me.



Any way, I could go on and on forever! Ample documentation on video and audio of the Cassette Culture Celebration will follow in the days and weeks to come!



These three days were some of the best times in my entire life, which I will cherish forever. I am grateful and thankful for the opportunities to bond with Chris, Jeff, Jerry, John, and Cathy, and to hang out with Lisa Miralia, Brian Callahan, Mike Jackson, Knox, Otho, Ron Daily, Endwar, Grey Tissue, and so many other nice people whose names I can't remember at the moment.



Special thanks to Jeff and Deb Chenault for their gracious hospitality, and for giving me such a nice and peaceful home to stay in while I was in Columbus. Big thanks also to Alison Colman for helping to organize the Cassette Culture Celebration with Jeff. Thanks to Ron Daily for live sound engineering at the fest. Also thanks to Rachel Rew Wagner for recording the entire event on video and audio.



Thank you thank you thank you to all of you. I love you all, everyone I met, new and old friends alike. I feel badly that I cannot remember the names of everybody I met. If we met and conversed and you read this, contact me with your name and I'll try to add you to the text above.



Photos on the front cover, starting top left and then clockwise:

- Frau McGee and Herr Phinney at Schmidt’s Sausage Haus. Photo by Jeff Chenault.

- left to right: Jeff Chenault, John M. Bennett, Chris Phinney, Cathy Bennett, Hal McGee, and Jerry Kranitz at Iron Grill. Photo by our waitress.

- Hal McGee, Jerry Kranitz, Jeff Chenault, and Chris Phinney at Cup O Joe. Photo by another customer.

- Catherine Mehrl Bennett and John M. Bennett in their home. Photo by Hal McGee.

- Eating German food dinner at CPAC - Jerry Kranitz (back to camera), and then clockwise: Jeff Chenault, Rob from Saginaw, Otho Thorn, Michael Thomas Jackson, Endwar (Andrew Russ), Lisa Miralia, and Chris Phinney. Photo by Hal McGee.

- Hal McGee with Lisa Miralia. Photo by Jeff Chenault.

- Photo above the album title: Brian Callahan, Jerry Kranitz, and Cathy Bennett. Photo by Hal McGee.



For those of you who have Facebook accounts you can view an album of 151 photos from the Columbus trip, here: 

www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.2325281094345226&type=3

Hal McGee.title: June 2023 Report
Hal McGee.about:
From June 1st through 30th, 2023 I made 326 recordings

of the sounds of my daily life in Gainesville, Florida, USA

with four Sony ICD-PX470 stereo digital dictaphones

that I carried with me in my pants pocket everywhere I went

- At the end of the month I mixed the recordings together

into what I call a dictaphone assemblage

using a random chance shuffle procedure

- This is my highly personal form of audio folk art

You will hear sounds from many different times, places, and spaces

occurring simultaneously as you listen

-- perhaps similar to the sensations of a 1960s Happening,

or a flea market or carnival, a county fair or a circus

Or perhaps you could imagine what it would be like to watch four home movies projected simultaneously

- You will help me to complete the audio work by active listening:

by directing your attention to the sounds

your mind will organize the sounds into unexpected forms

of music and experience

- You will hear mixed together:

my dog, Stanley

my brother Mark, Mom, Dad, and other family members,

neighbors, co-workers, grocery store employees,

public transportation, emergency vehicles, traffic, aircraft,

birds, thunderstorms, rain, wind,

and voice and memo recordings by Gerardo Colin, K.R. Seward,

and Rafael González

- Plus I played:

circuit bent Casio SK-1, KQ Unotone & GarageBand iPhone synths,

Moog Rogue and Behringer Poly D analog synthesizers,

transparent plastic ukulele, and two string pink dumpster guitar

- You will also hear the sounds of my brother playing percussion,

which I recorded through his closed bedroom door

- And thanks to Leslie Singer and Rafael González for ideas and inspirations

Hal McGee.title: a letter to my friends
Hal McGee.about:
Dear friends, from April 14th through May 22nd, 2023 I recorded the sounds of my daily life in Gainesville, Florida, USA with four Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones that I carried with me in my pocket wherever I went. You will hear 444 recordings from various times and spaces during that 39 day period randomly shuffled together in four simultaneous layers. You will hear me talking, my dog Stanley, my co-workers, some but not all family members (Dad and Mom and their dog Bailey, and my brother), Trevor Luke, neighbors, the postal delivery lady. Also, I played these instruments: circuit bent Casio SK-1, two string pink dumpster guitar, transparent plastic ukulele, KQ Unotone iPhone synth, red Casio CT-S200 tablehooter with a handle. You will also hear my brother, Mark McGee, play percussion. Additional audio recordings by K.R. Seward and Gerardo Colin.

I like to call this style of music or organized sound by the name "dictaphone assemblage audio folk art"!

Thanks to RRRafael Speedy Gonzálezszszsz and Leslie Singerrrrr for ideas and inspirations.



I encourage you to do other things while you listen, such as cooking, cleaning, laundry, household chores, answering mail, working on your visual art, riding the bus or subway, taking a walk, etc.



Plus if you feel like playing along and mixing in your own sounds, please by all means do so!



Please note that I have a potty mouth and that this album is peppered liberally with spicy language that is not suitable for job and family settings, and that I talk about some stuff that might make some people uncomfortable or just plain wonder WTF.

It’s my brain and my life that I am sharing with you!



Mail stuff to me! - send postcards, letters, tapes, CDs, records, collages, mail art, rubber stamp art, zines, chapbooks, gadgets, comix, drawings, stickers, poetry, paintings, etc and I will mail to you a homebrewed CDR of my homemade audio art in trade

Hal McGee

4230 SW 20th Lane

Apt. F

Gainesville, FL 32607

USA



Make homemade music great again.

Make mail art great again.

Make friendship great again.

Make internationalism great again.



I have been making my own homemade audio art since 1981 and I have postal-mailed literally thousands of my recordings since then. I feel an affinity for and kinship with the Mail Art community, and I feel strongly that the underground DIY music scene and Mail Art are interrelated. Both share the same roots, ideals and inspirations. Independence, Community, Cooperation and Internationalism.

Hal McGee.title: ONECx15
Hal McGee.about:
Composed by Michael Thomas Jackson

February 4-18 2023, Studio Knexiho, Winston-Salem NC USA

- an Electronic Cottage project

The composition “ONECx15” was realized through the exclusive participation of members belonging to the Electronic Cottage online music group. I had been invited by Hal McGee to curate a project for the site and solicited vocal and instrumental sound snippets (not to exceed 9 seconds) in the form of an open invitation to all members. Each respondent was in turn provided an original photograph from myself in lieu of a part in the overall score. The score itself uses traditional rhythmic notation for the gestures that serve as the generative material for most of the composition, and the sound material submitted by the participants take on the role of pitched material. The voicing was arranged in four parts as a sort of homage to the four-track tape recorder, an indispensable tool in my development as a musician. While members of the group will surely notice that their sounds have been edited somewhat, I did not process the material in any other way.

—Michael Thomas Jackson

- with the participation of:

Bryan Baker, Bert Vanden Berghe, Walter Campbell,

Osvaldo Cibils, Robert Clark, Max Julian Eastman,

Rafael González, Hal Harmon, Dylan Houser,

Maggie-Wynn Kingsford, Charlie Kramer, Steve Ladensack,

Al Margolis, Hal McGee, Bill Northcott, Andy Ortmann,

Jeremiah Paddock, Jay Decosta Peele, Chris Phinney,

Phil Rodrigues, Kevin Seward, Leslie Singer



While “ONECx15” is intended to be listened to as a single continuous composition, it can be structurally broken down into six sections:



1 Exposition (0-2:20)

2 Variance (2:21-6:40)

3 Kishterlude (6:41-7:22)

4 Lancing Tropes (7:23-9:45)

5 Earth Blues (9:46-12:46)

6 Coda (12:47-13:42)

Hal McGee.about:

sounds of my daily life and spoken words

featuring recordings, sounds, and other contributions by:

I talked a lot, and I played circuit bent Casio SK-1, two string pink dumpster guitar, KQ Unotone iPhone synth. I read excerpts from John M. Bennett's "Gravel Was The Future". I read movie reviews that I wrote of "Licorice Pizza", "France", and "Red Rocket"

is like listening to four cut-up sound collages at the same time

or watching four different films projected onto four screens

You are encouraged to do other things while you listen

Make your own sounds and let in sounds from the outside



The fifth track is "Vertical Zig-Zag", a 28-minute recording of a performance by Jeff Central, C. Mehrl Bennett, and John M. Bennett at the Frequency Fridays event on Friday, April 1st at the Columbus Arts Center in Columbus, Ohio. As you will hear by listening to April 2022 Report, I was scheduled to perform with Cathy, Jeff, and John at that event, but Delta Airlines made that impossible through their incompetence. My three friends performed any way (and they dedicated their performance to me), which made me feel better about things! Thanks to Alison Colman and The Fuse Factory

Hal McGee.title: May 15, 2022
Hal McGee.about:
On Sunday, May 15, 2022 I traveled to the Enzian Theater in Maitland, Florida (near Orlando) to attend a screening of the newly remastered version of David Lynch's 2006 film *Inland Empire*.



My friend Steve Ladensack accompanied me on the trip from Gainesville and we met our good friends Hal Harmon and Maggie-Wynn Magpie at the theater.



During the course of the day on May 15th I made 41 recordings with my trusty Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones of conversations with my friends, sounds at the theater, and during the trip to and from Maitland. Maggie-Wynn brought some pocket-sized noisemakers with her and I recorded her playing them shortly after we met in the Enzian parking lot.



On Wednesday evening, May 18th, while walking with my dog Stanley, I recorded an extemporaneous memoir of the events of Sunday the 15th.

On this May 15, 2022 dictaphone assemblage album you will hear my "review" of the day, mixed with sounds from the day itself.



You will also hear me playing my 2-string pink dumpster guitar, circuit bent Casio SK-1, and KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer.



dictaphone assemblage audio folk art

Hal McGee.title: Six Days in January
Hal McGee.about:
SEIS DÍAS EN ENERO

is an audio folk art dictaphone assemblage

conceived, organized and constructed by Hal McGee

consisting of digital dictaphone recordings

by Rafael González, Dylan Houser, and McGee

plus microcassette recordings by Leslie Singer (Girls On Fire)

with voice messages by Danny McGuire (Jiblit Dupree)

recorded during six days in January 2022, 19th through 24th



Think of this audio assemblage as a joyous, cacophonous 124-minute environment, similar to a 1960s-era Happening, with multiple simultaneous events occurring, shared with you with love

Listen to it closely, or as a background while you do other things, ignore it altogether, or listen to it in bits and pieces

Note the differences each time you listen

As you listen, open your windows and doors and let sounds from the outside mix with the assemblage, make your own sounds with your voice, radio, TV, Internet, tapes and discs, instruments and appliances



Hal McGee

Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphone recordings

from Gainesville and Micanopy, Florida

of the sounds of his daily life:

featuring Leslie Singer and her visit to Gainesville

spoken words and conversations with Leslie and others

at various restaurants, shops, and driving in automobiles

Hal's 64th birthday party

instrumental and tablehooter jams by Leslie and Hal

incidental sounds from Apartment Music shows 40 and 41

Stanley The Dog

with percussion by Mark McGee



Rafael González

Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphone recordings

from La Laguna, Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain

of these sound sources:

Monotron Delay, field recordings, shortwave, ModSynth App for Android, Moog Filtatron App for iPhone, KQ Unotone App for iPhone, PVC tube, paper, cardboard, plastic bags, water, doors, windows, toothpaste and toilets



Dylan Houser

Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphone recordings

from Lakeland, Brandon, and Gainesville, Florida,

and exploited the following for audio purposes:

KQ Unotone, Omni (online synth app courtesy of Femur Design), Noise Sculptor (another synth app, courtesy of Ruin Technology), SOMA Ether V2, live YouTube meteorologists slowed down, various sounds around my workplace, acoustic percussion via household objects, acoustic guitar, conversations throughout Apartment Music 40, crowd noise throughout Westfield Brandon Mall, and my stinkin’ voice



Leslie Singer

contributed microcassette recordings made with a Sony M-455

from New York City, and Gainesville and Micanopy, Florida

and tried out to join The Chipmunks during her 6 days of recordings and is still waiting to hear back whether she passed the audition



Danny McGuire (Jiblit Dupree) contributed voice messages of his satirical "un-woke" dark comedy routines via Facebook Messenger, which were recorded by Hal

Hal McGee.title: Four Days in March
Hal McGee.about:
* featuring Chris Phinney and Michael Thomas Jackson *

Four Days in March is a joyous celebration of friendship and an immersive audio experience created with love for you!

audio folk art dictaphone assemblage

recordings of everyday sounds mixed with synthesizer improvisations

recorded with three Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones

Friday, March 4th through Monday, March 7th 2022

during Phinney's and Jackson's historic visit to Gainesville Florida

and featuring miscellaneous sounds from Apartment Music 42 and 43

including synthesizer improvisations by Phinney, Jackson, and McGee

with additional synthesizer sounds by Lumen K

with voices and other sounds by:

Stanley, Chris Phinney, Michael Thomas Jackson, Lenny Pearlman, Lumen K, Maggie-Wynn Magpie, Danny McGuire, Jason Irvin, and other participants of AM42 and 43, plus my mom and dad, Harold and JoAn McGee. 

Conversations while drinking numerous cups of coffee, during recording sessions, at Apartment Music shows, and while eating at restaurants, such as Indian Cuisine Buffet, La Pasadita, Metro Diner, 4 Rivers Smokehouse, Kabab House, 43rd Street Deli, and BurgerFi.

Also with sounds recorded on Friday morning and afternoon before Phinney's arrival, at the Gainesville Regional Airport, while taking Stanley on walks, and in Micanopy, Florida including the cemetery, plus in Hal's pants pocket.

Special credit goes to Lenny Pearlman, who suggested two of the track titles.

Included is an excerpt of Jiblit Dupree's performance of "I Always Fuck It Up" at Apartment Music 42.

The photo of Hal on the cover is by Chris Phinney.

Hal McGee.title: Dos Pollas
Hal McGee.about:
*Dos Pollas* is a split album of microcassette audio folk art consisting of 30 minutes of recordings by Rafael González and 30 minutes by Hal McGee. We are happy to present this album to you with joy and we hope that it will bring you fun and happiness.



Rafael wrote this about his collage titled "Dos Pollas en la playa":

I have used field recordings of my plane trip and my stay in Gijón (Asturias, Spain) July and August 2021, Casio PT-80, TV sounds, flute, Saucillator Android app, ModSynth Android app, and shortwave radio.



On his "microcassette assemblage por Dos Pollas" Hal mixed together recordings from three microcassettes he recorded during July and August 2021. You will hear spoken words and dream diaries by Hal, sounds from Hal's daily life including his interactions with his dog Stanley, neighbors, co-workers, family members, and grocery store employees. You will also hear sounds from Hal's shortwave radio, and him playing KQ Unotone iPhone synth, Casio CT-S200RD, and two string pink dumpster guitar.

Hal McGee.title: BANANA SPLIT
Hal McGee.about:
BANANA SPLIT

Part 1 of the split:

-30 minutes of new recordings by Girls On Fire (Leslie Singer)

-- manic collage of voice cut-ups, punk guitar, highjacked pop songs, electronics



Part 2 of the split:

- 30 minutes of new recordings by Hal McGee

-- microcassette audio folk art assemblages of daily sounds, spoken words, and shortwave radio



Dedicated to the memory of Dave Fuglewicz



\\\\\\\\\



Girls On Fire — 



Vocals and lyrics by Leslie Singer except for the “I am the Composer” section of “I Want to Bodysurf in Vomit”. Vocals and lyrics on that section are by Laura Cottingham.



Leslie would also like to credit Oliver Harris, Simon Reynolds,

Starship and The Residents' The Third Reich 'n Roll for lyrical inspiration.



Sounds were made with the help of the Korg Monotron, Monotron Duo and Delay, various Teenage Engineering Pocket Operators, the lil toy washing machine contact mic (by Lucy Bonk), Fender Squier guitar, Roland Cube amp, Behringer WASP synthesizer, Electro-Harmonix Black Russian Big Muff Pi fuzz pedal, $19 Felby microphone and Yamaha MG06 mixer.



Tracks recorded from January 2019 through July 4, 2021 with the help of a Sony microcassette recorder M-560V and two wonderful Sony ICD-PX470 digital recorders.



Special thanks to Hal McGee for inviting me to do this split album with him and for being such an inspiration and guiding light. And much love and appreciation to all of my fellow ECers! And a special shout out to Daisy!



/////////



Hal McGee —



recorded with four Sony microcassette recorders, June 2021

— co-starring Stanley — with the sounds of — spoken words by me, Lumen K's voice, shortwave radio, neighbors, scags and hustlers, co-workers, thunderstorms, the UPS truck, hipsters in black clothing with sunglasses, electronic monitors, cable mistake, rrrrrrrrrrrrr, mockingbird, who am I to say?, Stan is alone only 11 hours on three days a week, microcassette assemblage environments, ice cream truck tunes, the one thing wrong with my 2-string pink dumpster guitar, Keema Aloo Mattar, in an alternative historical fantasy reality, will you be my Pirate Robot Lover?, two string pink dumpster guitar, freedom from fear, could and will and did survive 2020, real American coffee served here, this is MY microcassette recorder!, Happy Birthday to You!, See Something Say Something, "I got my Grizzly!" ...



---------



On August 9, 2021 BANANA SPLIT was included in the list of "The Best Experimental Music on Bandcamp: July 2021 --  daily.bandcamp.com/best-experimental/the-best-experimental-music-on-bandcamp-july-2021



 Here is the review by Marc Masters:

Leslie Singer—who records as Girls on Fire—and Hal McGee are legends of the cassette underground. Both have made unpredictable audio work on tape since the early ‘80s, and they’ve been friends and supporters of each other for nearly as long. For a new split release, Singer blends sound art with musical homage and parody. On the 28-minute “I Want to Bodysurf in Vomit,” she mixes absurd songs, repetitive beats and samples, and comically-timed references to pop music into a dizzying aural amusement park ride. McGee’s approach to audio is more documentarian. He often carries a microcassette recorder around with him, capturing environmental sounds and his own verbal musings. His piece “Super Action Microcassette Assemblage” is a vintage example of this self-created form, as he injects self-aware references to his own process into a voice-in-head pastiche of mysterious speech and noise.

Hal McGee.title: December 2020 Report Personal Mix
Hal McGee.about:
December 2020 Report Personal Mix

dictaphone assemblage audio folk art by Hal McGee

featuring Dylan Houser



I recorded sounds of my daily life in the month of December 2020 during the isolation of the COVID-19 era using two Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones: dream diaries, my dog Stanley (Lindsey Barkingham), neighbors, co-workers, family members, KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, circuit bent Casio RapMan, Yamaha Reface CS synth, 2-string pink dumpster guitar, street sounds, emergency vehicles, the hospital where I work, and Publix grocery store. I loaded these same sounds onto two additional Sony dictaphones and then assembled a mix of the four dictaphones playing back the sounds in random-shuffle mode through a Behringer mixer directly into Audacity, with very little tweaking by me during the on-the-fly mix.



This December 2020 Personal Mix audio album features my friend Dylan Houser who traveled from his home in Lakeland, Florida and visited me on Friday, December 11th. You can hear his voice, and him playing his KQ Unotone iPhone synth and my 2-string pink dumpster guitar prominently in the audio mix.



///

The full title of the third track is "Damaged Beatings - My War is Over (if you want it) - the Process of Weeding Out Who's Naughty or Nice" by BARK FLAG. Assembled by Dylan Houser from dictaphone recordings that he made of him and me improvising on KQ Unotone iPhone synths, him playing my 2-string pink dumpster guitar, and Lindsey Barkingham barking.



\\\

This album is related to and consists of audio materials that were also used on December 2020 Report by Harold Schellinx and Hal McGee —  halmcgee.bandcamp.com/album/december-2020-report

Hal McGee.title: December 2020 Report
Hal McGee.about:
December 2020 Report - a collaboration

The two Harolds recorded sounds of their daily lives in Montreuil and Gainesville during the month of December 2020 and the Harold in Gainesville mixed the sounds together in a 4-layered dictaphone assemblage.



Harold Schellinx:

Sounds recorded on a ZOOM H2 digital recorder of my daily doings in the month of December 2020, most of which I spent corona-confined and/or curfew-ed inside my Montreuil apartment on the east side of Paris, teaching online to a variety of students on subjects ranging from intuitionistic mathematics to the history of the postmodern in contemporary music, conversing online or on telephone with family and friends (in English, French, Dutch, Limburgish) reading or speaking to myself (in German, Dutch), humming and singing, sometimes playing the piano, manipulating electronic sound toys or Animal Crossing, going down the stairs to collect mail and outside to go shopping in the neighbourhood, either on foot or on bicycle, only on less than a handful of days taking the metro to the city: once to stock asian food at Tang Frères, once to join friends at The Film Gallery on the 22nd when we did our 71st unPublic and finally then on December 31st to La Générale Nord-Est Mouton, where I ended the year performing the assembling/dissembling of these same recordings as part of the Antivirus 101 Placard. 

unpublic.bandcamp.com/album/paris-22-december-2020



 Hal McGee:

I recorded sounds of my daily life in Gainesville, Florida in the month of December 2020 during the isolation of the COVID-19 era using two Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphones: my dog Stanley, neighbors, co-workers, family members, KQ Unotone iPhone synthesizer, circuit bent Casio RapMan, Yamaha Reface CS synth, 2-string pink dumpster guitar, street sounds, emergency vehicles, the hospital where I work, and Publix grocery store, with contributions by Dylan Houser (who visited me one day).



/////////

You can view a slideshow movie consisting of 434 photos that Harold and I took during the month of December, with its own unique audio assemblage mix, on YouTube —  youtu.be/AfMlJBAQEV8



 \\\\\\\\\

Hal McGee.title: EC Split 25
Hal McGee.about:
EC Split 25: Mi Casa, Su Casa

by dabodab and Magic Bullet 

an Electronic Cottage release

[Please note that each track on the album has its own artwork panel]



dabodab

Mi Casa, Su Casa

composed by Brian F. Baker

 

Spoken word: Marilyn Baker, telling about the houses she grew up in.

 

Bryan Baker: Samples, electronics, Reaktor, Obsidian, Korg Wavestate, Schoenhut Toy Piano, Zoom H5N Recorder.



Magic Bullet are Mick Magic & Skit Zoyd, who play and do stuff to; two telephones, a tractor, the Irish sea and its winds, two vacuum cleaners, a boiler, a steam iron, several running taps, a tumble dryer, a washing machine, two dehumidifiers, a dishwasher, a cooker hood, a kettle, a microwave, a fan oven, a wind-up gramophone, a fan, a television, 2 Solpadeine tablets dissolving in a beaker of water (*other painkillers are available!), an extractor fan, a shower, a WC, an electric toothbrush, a hairdryer, an electric shaver and its cleaning / charging station, ‘whistle lips’, a toy xylophone, a toy recorder, a battery operated guitar toy, a Peppa Pig trumpet toy, a paper shredder and a printer.



I live in a house called Asgard in the village of Knott End-On-Sea in Lancashire, England, as does Skit, my partner in the band. But we do not live in the same house, his is somewhere beyond several trans-dimensional voids in a parallel reality. We are told by an ageing scientist that there are 25 such parallel dimensions, and in one of these, our house is occupied by an American writer of some repute. This is the story of his visit to our Asgard, and how the portal device he brought with him allowed us to look back through in to his. And he did not just wish to see our house, he also wished to hear it. What else could we say but “Mi casa, su casa”...



The Hostess is played by Samantha Magic

Unscheduled guest appearances by Twizzle Magic

And our very special guest as The Traveller: Owen Knight

All tracks conceived and realised by Magic & Zoyd

Recorded and mixed in The Mmatterialisation Chamber, September 2020

Published by Mmatterial, all rights reserved, but we don’t bite fingers

Magic Bullet track artwork by Mick Magic

Cover art ‘Skit, Bryan & Mick’ by Kev Trundley  (connyplankton.bandcamp.com)

 Background, additional artwork and layout by Mick Magic

For further info:  www.mickmagic.net

Hal McGee.title: EC Split 21
Hal McGee.about:
EC Split 21

by Thomas Milovac and Massimo Magee

an Electronic Cottage release



\\\\\\\\\

Murals (for Maxo Vanka)

Thomas Milovac - Double Bass, Voice 

Recorded in Orlando, FL 10/2020



“Murals” is a solo improvisation for double bass and voice influenced by the work of Croatian-American painter Maxo Vanka. Vanka’s striking murals at the St. Nicholas Croatian church in Millvale, Pennsylvania juxtapose elements of traditional Croatian life, religious imagery, industrialization, and the horrors of war that lingered in the minds of people after the end of the First World War. One example of this juxtaposition is a mural, at the St. Nicholas church, of a Nun ominously veiled with a gas mask over her face. “Murals” aims to explore the juxtaposition of musical ideas in a manner influenced by Vanka’s work and create a vast, sonic mural for the listener.



/////////

Welcome to the Real World

Massimo Magee - clarinet, virtual piano

Recorded at home in London 15th August 2020



I've called the piece 'Welcome to the Real World' because it progressively strips back the layers of the constructed fantasy playing environment I've made for myself during this locked down year until it gets to just the raw zoom-recorded sounds of my clarinet in the studio with the noise of cars going by and people walking past etc, before putting back on the layers of make-believe for a finale. The clarinet part is a solo improvisation, recorded in my studio in one take and with no edits but with concert hall reverb later applied to most of it, and then there are also virtual piano intro and outro parts derived from the clarinet playing and interacting with it. My clarinet's a 1953 Selmer centered tone, so I like to imagine this constructed piano-clarinet duo in a non-existent hall is more what it might have been used to during its heyday in the 50s or 60s, with a gradual waking up to the realities of a musician alone in a locked-down 2020, competing with the noises of a world outside that probably doesn't care much for it in the main.

Hal McGee.title: EC SPLIT 20
Hal McGee.about:
EC SPLIT 20

by Anton Mobin & Harold Schellinx

an Electronic Cottage release



« Principe d'Intersection »



These 24 'lullabies for a sick world' were composed and recorded (in the months August, September and October of this so dramatic year 2020) by Anton Mobin and Harold Schellinx. They were made in pairs, using what they call the 'intersection principle', a working method that resulted in these 2 x 12 highly personal compositions, all in the respective authors very own style, that, however, pairwise have a 'melodic' overlap -their intersection- and the exact same duration.



Think of these intersections as the spines of a species of two-winged creatures, where each wing corresponds to one of the two corresponding pieces. But as the creature may flap and fold its wings, there is, as a consequence a third dimension: you may collapse each pair into a third one, the mix or union of the two ...



For more information see the pdf file that comes with the digital download, or visit  harsmedia.com/SoundBlog/Archief/00858.php

Hal McGee.title: EC Split 23
Hal McGee.about:
EC Split 23

by Ben Presto and Jeremiah Paddock

an Electronic Cottage release



\\\\\\\\\

Ben Presto

(tracks 1-6)



Jeremiah and I, after throwing down a series of brainstorming ideas for the EC Split Album, agreed on the theme that it would be good for both of us, and we came to the "journey".

But what do we mean by "journey" (voyage, trip, etc.)? The naked and raw meaning/sign or the metaphor of it?

It made me think of all sorts of journeys, of the vastness of knowledge... of everything except a vacation!

From the voyage with psychotropic substances to death, from nightmare to infinite silence, from physical escape from one place to another (better? worse?) to that of a book, or a film, or a music album.

Many ideas have been suggested to me by the films. I could have pulled out an album of at least 2 hours!

So I made (unrecognizable!) plunderphonics, fishing with full hands from every source of sounds/ideas.

In the titles (as in the cover) there are tributes to "The Trip" by Corman, to "Dead Man" by Jarmusch, to "The 7th Voyage of Sinbad", to "The Twilight Zone", to Wenders, to Carpenter, to library music as well as darker prog and electronics.

More obscure I said, because the whole thing seems to sound very gloomy, but, I swear, I did a great search to get there to an aural, synaesthetic experience.

I hope I did my best!



/////////

Jeremiah Paddock

(tracks 7-22)



Patrizio and I talked about journeys as being a theme or idea for the split. My physical ability to make exciting or long journeys was dramatically shortened by a disease. With the advent of COVID my work schedule changed and I was sent to work at a different location. The new location was 20 minutes from my home and on the drive there was a traffic circle that I drove through everyday, twice a day. I was not in a great place mentally and felt trapped in my own endless roundabout. More and more time was spent trying to map my mental journeys. I began composing guitar loops in the morning before work, trying to put some of these feelings into music. Depending on the day I really think you are able to hear my mood and state of mind.

Hal McGee.title: EC Split 8
Hal McGee.about:
EC SPLIT 8

by Rafael González and Zebra Mu



Rafael González:

Cassettes, microcassettes, and their respective recorders, radio, shortwave, radio manipulated, Korg Monotron, Korg Monotron Delay, distortion pedals, Alexis Microverb 4, Mbira, toy guitar, school metallophone, and broken electronic game. Recorded August 2020 with Sony ICD PX-470 stereo digital dictaphone.



Zebra Mu is Michael Ridge.

Sound sources: various portable cassette recorders, answering machine message tape, tape loops, field recordings, contact microphone, junk metal, garage door and springs. The tape loops were recorded and assembled between 14 August – 23 August 2020, with the final composition being recorded in one take. Made with no FX pedals or digital processing. 



mridge.bandcamp.com

  michaelridge.wordpress.com

  quaggacurious.wordpress.com



 ---------



Review by author Jerry Kranitz:



EC Split 8 features group members Rafael González and Zebra Mu (aka Michael Ridge). I’ve heard very little of Rafael’s work and none of Michael’s, so I’m pleased to get acquainted with their work. The two make a good pairing, both creating sound collages, though both are very different from one another.



Rafael’s first track is a cut-up collage of static, tones, and radio/television samples. I like the way he deftly slices and dices, setting a steadily flowing ‘groove’ with static, music and voices. It’s a nifty balance between frenetic chaos and Collage ‘n’ Roll. About halfway through things get briefly spacey before transitioning to frequently shifting sequences… a noise blast here, a flurry of voices there, flying saucer and ghostly effects, water drippy gurgly effects. Lots going on! The next track is similar but more hyper herky-jerky, with cut-up collage channel surfing and more of that noise and samples ‘groove’. I found my head bopping at times to what I’ll be darned ‘feels’ like a beat! But oh, that shrill piercing electronic cricket at the end!

After a lightning quick voice manipulation, we’re treated to a glom of what sounds like crackling paper, static waves, string manipulations, toy instruments, alien oscillations, and voices. ‘Microcassette (I Need A Compass)’ is Rafael’s final track and my favorite of his set. It’s a fun collage of Japanese and other language voices and singing, plus lots of radio. It’s humorous, artfully/imaginatively collaged, and the result is like one big psychedelic sound-art brain sloshing.



Zebra Mu’s ‘side’ is a single 30-minute piece titled ‘Answering Machine Messages For John And Junk Metal Tape Loops’. An underlying drugged, wavering, looped ‘song’… it sounds like a misty blend of rock songs… provides the anchor for a succession of answering machine voices. If this is Michael’s answering machine, he gets some interestingly incidental calls. There’s also an ongoing flurry of what sounds like backwards effects that feel like knives being hurled lightning fast. The overall sensation is simultaneously spectral and lysergic. It’s fairly low-key for a while but near the halfway mark the volume and intensity level kicks up dramatically, until we find ourselves in the midst of a high-octane collage battle of metal, clatter, scrapes and scratches. Similar to Rafael, Michael also creates of sense of chaotic rhythmic flow, as if the cast of the stage show Rent got into a rumble in a Cuisinart.

LOTS from both artists for the attentive listener to wrap their heads around!

Hal McGee.title: EC Split 9
Hal McGee.about:
EC SPLIT 9

Al Margolis and not half



Al Margolis: percussion/objects, alto and tenor saxophones



not half is Al Conroy

Waldorf Microwave XT synth, Logic Pro 9, location recordings; Hecla Island, my furnace and Basil (1993-2014), summer rain in Winnipeg.



---------



Review by author Jerry Kranitz:



EC Split 9 features EC Group members Al Margolis and not half (aka Al Conroy).



I have experienced Al Margolis in live performance and his two contributions to this set immediately brought to mind how he created his sounds during those shows. I recall Al stretched belly down straight out on the floor, putting his entire body into play as he took his quietly developing sounds where they needed to go. Putting those images out of my mind for a moment, I’m hearing on the 12-minute ‘al4haldrums’ what sounds like the slow moan of creaking doors, seamlessly interspersed with crackling waves, and even identifiable percussion taps, and near the end of the piece it’s almost like percussive, crackly, scratchy water flowing. Al quietly and subtly scratches, drags, tickles, and in various other ways manipulates the percussion, saxophones, and ‘objects’ in his employ.



The nearly 18-minute ‘al4halvoices’ is relatively action packed, creating a similar flow, but with a breathy, drawn out saxophone blow. And by ‘breathy’ I mean you can hear the sax but the sound is more blow/breathe based. The sounds vary and combined with weird whiney voicings, at times sound like a fly buzzing around a solo sax player who is stuck between short wave radio stations. At times it gets a little symphonic, with the fly becoming a swarm, though overall the sax manipulations and voices quietly flow and evolve, with the focus throughout being on SOUND. And all throughout the images of Al performing his sounds kept popping back into my head. (He was scheduled to perform here again this past April but, y’know…)



Al Conroy’s work is new to me and his contribution, titled ‘winsomeness’, is a single nearly 30-minute piece. Field recordings of a gently flowing stream set the pace for a haunting electronic soundtrack. The music starts off with a Residents Mark Of The Mole vibe, though with a wavering psychedelic edge. I like the way the music develops, from eerily supernatural to spaced out contemplative. But the music is a multi-themed soundtrack, the stream being the only constant. The music finishes, only to shortly after start again with a more eerily sinister theme. Yet another new theme consists of spaced out synth waves, raising the volume and intensity level, that are simultaneously ominous and meditatively moody. Kudos to Al for captivating thematic development throughout!

Also sneaked in are some snippets of sound provided by Lezet, at the end of this track (with his kind permission of course!) :-) 



www.brunk.be

 Lezet was originally a name Igor Jovanovic had in mind for his high school crossover metal band that never came to be, and although the name itself came to be associated with experimental music (and a mattress factory in Macedonia), Igor remained fascinated with the idea of making eclectic/experimental metal, and would occasionally make a metal-oriented track here and there. Almost two years after a great split with Dislexic Fudgicle, it was time to do another fantastic full-on metal split.

Igor is currently a member of Lezet, Koi Karp, Gid, FiXtion.
